the folder you mount to must exist and is an empty folder
yes, folder. Like a windows folder, you mount partitions to folders
the folder will then be the access point to the data on the partition, linux doesn't use restrictuive drive letters, it has a file structure and you simply attach data storages where you want
its a lot more flexible
/media/media is simply a folder created by udev, the partition is then mounted there so that when you access that folder you will be shown the contents of the partition you mounted
if you have existing partitions, if you use the custom partitioning, you can specify the partition to be mounted and put in fstab during install (if memory serves)
use UUIDs and you'll have fewer issues
